title: Foundations & Measurement
expanded_description: In physics, quantities are classified as either scalars or vectors. Scalars are fully described by a magnitude (a number and unit) alone. Vectors require both a magnitude and a direction to be fully specified. This distinction is fundamental because vector quantities follow different mathematical rules—they can be added, subtracted, and multiplied in ways that account for direction, not just size.

core_concept.principle: A scalar has only magnitude; a vector has both magnitude and direction. Direction makes vectors behave differently from scalars in calculations.
core_concept.explanation: Imagine telling a friend to meet you '5 kilometers away.' That's not enough—they need to know which direction: north, east, etc. The distance (5 km) is a scalar; the displacement (5 km north) is a vector. Many physical quantities, like force, velocity, and acceleration, are vectors because direction matters. Understanding this distinction is the first step toward analyzing motion and interactions.

image.alt: Diagram comparing scalar (just number) and vector (number + direction)
image.caption: Scalars have only magnitude; vectors have both magnitude and direction.

sections.introduction: Some physical quantities can be completely described by a single number and its unit. These are called scalars.

key_concept.definition: A scalar quantity has only magnitude (size). It does not include direction.
key_concept.context: Scalars obey the ordinary rules of arithmetic. You can add, subtract, multiply, and divide them just like ordinary numbers. For example, if you have 3 kg of apples and 2 kg of oranges, the total mass is 5 kg—simple addition.

principles.statement: Scalars are specified by a numerical value and a unit. No direction is needed.
principles.application: Any quantity that doesn't involve orientation in space is a scalar.
principles.example: Temperature, mass, time, energy, speed, volume.

principles.statement: Scalars combine using the usual rules of algebra.
principles.application: You can add, subtract, multiply, and divide scalars without worrying about direction.

classifications.behavior: All have magnitude only; no direction needed.

image.alt: Examples of scalar quantities: mass, time, temperature
image.caption: Scalars are quantities that don't require direction.

sections.introduction: Many physical quantities have a directional aspect—it's not enough to know how much; you also need to know which way. These are vectors.

key_concept.definition: A vector quantity has both magnitude and direction. It is represented by a directed line segment (arrow).
key_concept.context: If you push a box with a force of 10 N, the effect depends on whether you push north, south, up, or down. Force is a vector. Similarly, displacement, velocity, and acceleration are vectors because direction matters.

principles.statement: Vectors require two pieces of information: how much (magnitude) and which way (direction).
principles.application: When specifying a vector, you must include both parts.
principles.example: A displacement of $5\text{ m}$ east—the magnitude is 5 m, the direction is east.

principles.statement: Vectors are drawn as arrows. The length represents magnitude; the arrowhead points in the direction.
principles.application: This visual helps understand vector relationships.
principles.example: A force of 20 N upward is drawn as an arrow pointing up, length proportional to 20 N.

principles.statement: Vectors do not add like ordinary numbers—direction must be considered.
principles.application: Adding two vectors requires methods like tip-to-tail or parallelogram rule (covered in 1.6).
principles.example: Walking 3 m east then 4 m north results in a displacement of $5\text{ m}$ northeast, not 7 m.

classifications.behavior: All have magnitude and direction; they combine according to vector rules.

image.alt: Examples of vector quantities: displacement, velocity, force
image.caption: Vectors require direction for complete description.

sections.introduction: To work with vectors, we need a clear way to write and draw them.

key_concept.definition: Vectors can be represented symbolically with boldface or an arrow, and graphically as arrows.
key_concept.context: In textbooks, you'll see $\vec{A}$ or $\mathbf{A}$ for a vector. Its magnitude is written as $|\vec{A}|$ or simply $A$ (without bold or arrow). Graphically, the arrow's length corresponds to magnitude, and its orientation gives direction.

principles.statement: Vectors are often written with an arrow: $\vec{v}$ or in bold: $\mathbf{v}$. The magnitude is $v$ or $|\vec{v}|$.
principles.application: This distinguishes vectors from scalars in equations.
principles.example: $\vec{F} = m\vec{a}$ means force and acceleration are vectors; mass is a scalar.

principles.statement: An arrow is drawn with length proportional to magnitude, pointing in the direction of the vector.
principles.application: Used in diagrams to visualize vector addition and resolution.
principles.example: A vector of 10 m east is an arrow 10 units long pointing right (if east is right).

principles.statement: When drawing vectors, choose a scale so that the arrow fits on the page while maintaining correct relative lengths.
principles.application: e.g., 1 cm = 5 m, so a 20 m vector is drawn 4 cm long.

worked_examples.title: Drawing a Vector
worked_examples.problem: Draw a vector representing a displacement of 30 m at an angle of 30° north of east. Use a scale of 1 cm = 10 m.

step_by_step.explanation: Magnitude 30 m, scale 1 cm = 10 m → arrow length = $30/10 = 3\text{ cm}$.
Let right (east) be 0°, then measure 30° upward from east (north of east).
Draw a 3 cm line at 30° from east, with arrowhead at the tip.

worked_examples.final_answer: A 3 cm arrow pointing 30° north of east.

image.alt: Diagram showing vector notation and graphical representation
image.caption: Vectors are drawn as arrows; symbolic notation uses arrows or bold.

sections.introduction: Vectors have specific properties that govern how they can be manipulated.

key_concept.definition: Vectors can be equal, negative, multiplied by scalars, and added—each operation has a geometric interpretation.
key_concept.context: Understanding these properties prepares you for vector addition (Section 1.6) and later topics like components and dot/cross products.

classifications.value: Two vectors are equal if they have the same magnitude and the same direction.
characteristics: Equal vectors may be drawn in different locations; they are considered the same if magnitude and direction match.
Position does not matter—vectors are free to move (in basic physics).

examples.explanation: A displacement of 5 m north from point A and 5 m north from point B are equal vectors.

classifications.value: The negative of a vector $\vec{A}$ is a vector with the same magnitude but opposite direction, denoted $-\vec{A}$.
characteristics: Adding a vector and its negative yields zero vector.

examples.explanation: If $\vec{v} = 20\text{ m/s}$ north, then $-\vec{v} = 20\text{ m/s}$ south.

classifications.value: Multiplying a vector by a positive scalar changes its magnitude but not direction. Multiplying by a negative scalar reverses direction.

examples.explanation: If $\vec{F} = 10\text{ N}$ right, then $2\vec{F} = 20\text{ N}$ right, and $-3\vec{F} = 30\text{ N}$ left.

image.alt: Diagrams showing equal vectors, negative vectors, and scalar multiplication
image.caption: Vector properties: equality, negative, scalar multiplication.

sections.introduction: A common skill is identifying whether a given quantity is a scalar or a vector. This determines how it behaves mathematically.

key_concept.definition: Ask: Does direction matter for this quantity? If yes, it's a vector; if no, it's a scalar.
key_concept.context: For example, temperature doesn't have a direction—it's a scalar. Force always has a direction—it's a vector.

principles.statement: If you can meaningfully ask 'which way?' for a quantity, it is likely a vector.
principles.application: Velocity: which way? → vector. Mass: which way? → nonsense → scalar.
principles.example: Speed vs velocity: speed (scalar) doesn't have direction; velocity (vector) does.

principles.statement: Some quantities can be scalar in one context and vector in another? Usually not—it's inherent.
principles.application: Distance (scalar) vs displacement (vector); work (scalar) vs force (vector).

worked_examples.title: Classify Quantities
worked_examples.problem: Identify each as scalar or vector: (a) 5 m, (b) 5 m north, (c) 20°C, (d) 9.8 m/s² downward, (e) 100 J, (f) 50 N at 30°.

step_by_step.explanation: Energy is a scalar (work, kinetic energy).

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) scalar, (b) vector, (c) scalar, (d) vector, (e) scalar, (f) vector.

sections.introduction: Students often confuse certain pairs of quantities. Understanding the difference is crucial.

classifications.value: Distance (scalar) is the total path length traveled. Displacement (vector) is the straight-line change in position from start to end, including direction.
characteristics: Distance ignores direction; displacement always includes direction.
Distance can never decrease; displacement can be zero even if distance is not.

examples.explanation: Walking 3 m east then 4 m north: distance = 7 m, displacement = 5 m northeast.

classifications.value: Speed (scalar) is the rate of change of distance. Velocity (vector) is the rate of change of displacement—it includes direction.
characteristics: Average speed = total distance / time; average velocity = displacement / time.
An object moving in a circle at constant speed has changing velocity (because direction changes).

examples.explanation: A car going around a track at 30 m/s has constant speed, but its velocity changes as it turns.

image.alt: Diagram showing distance (path length) vs displacement (straight line)
image.caption: Distance is scalar; displacement is vector.

key_terms.definition: A physical quantity that has magnitude only, no direction.
A physical quantity that has both magnitude and direction.
The size or amount of a quantity; for a vector, it is the length of the arrow.
The orientation of a vector in space, often given as an angle or cardinal direction.
A vector representing the change in position of an object.
A vector representing the rate of change of displacement.
A scalar representing the total path length traveled.
A scalar representing the rate of change of distance.
A vector with the same magnitude but opposite direction.
Multiplying a vector by a scalar changes its magnitude (and direction if scalar is negative).

summary: Physics distinguishes between scalar and vector quantities. Scalars have only magnitude (e.g., mass, time, temperature, distance, speed, energy). Vectors have both magnitude and direction (e.g., displacement, velocity, acceleration, force). Vectors are represented graphically as arrows—length indicates magnitude, arrowhead indicates direction. Symbolically, vectors are written with an arrow ($\vec{v}$) or in bold, and magnitude as $|\vec{v}|$ or $v$. Key properties: two vectors are equal if they have the same magnitude and direction; the negative of a vector has same magnitude but opposite direction; multiplying a vector by a positive scalar changes magnitude only, by a negative scalar reverses direction. Common confusions include distance vs displacement and speed vs velocity—the vector versions include direction. Recognizing whether a quantity is scalar or vector is essential for applying correct mathematical operations, especially addition, which will be covered next.

practice_questions.question: Classify each as scalar or vector: (a) 10 m/s east, (b) 10 m/s, (c) 9.8 N, (d) 9.8 N downward, (e) 2 hours, (f) 3 km².
practice_questions.answer: (a) vector, (b) scalar, (c) scalar (if just magnitude? Actually '9.8 N' without direction is scalar; if direction implied it would be vector. Here it's just magnitude, so scalar), (d) vector, (e) scalar, (f) scalar.

practice_questions.question: What is the difference between distance and displacement?
practice_questions.answer: Distance is a scalar representing the total path length traveled, regardless of direction. Displacement is a vector representing the straight-line change in position from start to finish, including direction.

practice_questions.question: A car travels 5 km east, then 5 km west. What is the total distance traveled? What is the displacement?
practice_questions.answer: Distance = 5 km + 5 km = 10 km. Displacement = 0 km (since it returns to start).

practice_questions.question: If vector $\vec{A}$ has magnitude 10 units pointing north, what is the magnitude and direction of $-2\vec{A}$?
practice_questions.answer: Magnitude = $2 \times 10 = 20$ units. Direction = south (opposite to north).

practice_questions.question: Explain why velocity is a vector but speed is a scalar.
practice_questions.answer: Velocity includes direction (e.g., 20 m/s north) while speed is just magnitude (20 m/s). A change in direction changes velocity even if speed remains constant.

practice_questions.question: Draw a vector representing a force of 25 N at 120° (measured counterclockwise from east). Use a scale of 1 cm = 5 N.
practice_questions.answer: Length = $25/5 = 5$ cm. Draw a 5 cm arrow at 120° from east (i.e., 30° west of north or 60° north of west? Actually 120° from east is 30° past north, so pointing somewhat northwest).
